The Academic Council is now considering faculty
promotions, and there is a grave possibility that
financial problems may have a disproportionately large
influence on their deliberations. Both Academic Council
members and Dean Benton insist that they wish only
to look at a professor's merit, but it is likely that they
will give in to budgetary pressures. The results of such
narrowness can only be disastrous for the vital core of
this University, and its academic program.
The financial difficulty surrounding the promotions
issue is but another sad example of the desperate crisis
at Hopkins. For the first time, the Academic Council
has to judge promotions all at once, rather than each
promotion separately. This is a wise approach to the
problem,for it permits a total assessment of the faculty
situation, which, hopefully, will allow a more judicious
examination of all factors involved in promotions.
Unfortunately, this is the sort of approach which lends
itself more to bare monetary concerns than to a genuine
regard for academic quality. Junior faculty and
associate professors who find themselves passed over
because of financial reasons will be quite tempted to
leave for other schools that can offer them greater
prestige and a higher salary. Hopkins is already suffering from a shortage of faculty, or to be more exact,
faculty willing to teach; more faculty departures,
coupled with the present hiring freeze, could do serious
damage to the calibre and stature of the Hopkins
academic program.

indirectly influencing those who are looking at promotions. The influence is, of course, in actuality
neither
nor
indirect
unimportant.
But we urge, for the sake of the University, that
promotions be on the basis of merit alone. The
necessary sacrifices can then come from further cutbacks in the non-academic areas of the University.

Francis Carlson
Editors Note:

1)r. Francis D. Carlson, Biophyics, was scheduled to appear at the Forum on it
on April 7,
but withdrew when he detected a "decidedly

felt his position had been misrepresented in a

present at the Forum.
My views on the relationship of universities
within our society to classified research
were formed during the period of and immediately following the Second World War.
The MacMahon bill passed then enabled the
establishment of close civilian control over
our atomic energy program. The vital issue
today is essentially the issue that arose over
the control of atomic energy in 1945, namely,
should the application of science to the
development of military technology be
conducted solely by the military under
military secrecy or should it be conducted
under the guidance and full knowledge of
responsible, authorized civilian groups. I
took a stand in favor of civilian control in
1945 and I have no intentions of abandoning it.
I do not contend that our civilian agencies
for controlling and monitoring military
• research have been entirely successful, or as
effective as we would like. They have been, in
my opinion, infinitely better than no civilian
control at all. Without some civilian involvement, however imperfect it might be,
military research would vanish under the
cloak of complete military secrecy.
Some of you may doubt the capability of
the military-industrial complex to carry out
the development of military technology in
total secrecy. In 1942, the Manhattan District
was established under the Army Corps of
Engineers for the purposes of manufacturing fissionable materials. This was done
in complete secrecy. Not even the workers
who built the plants knew what they were
doing.
In the absence of a duly authorized civilian
control panel, university students, faculty,
administrators, and trustees are certainly
no less obligated than any other member of
our society for shouldering the responsibility
of adequately monitoring universty sponsored military research They have, in my
opinion, the greater obligation to see that
this responsibility is discharged.
How should civilian involvement in the

management of military research be
organized? I do not know the entire answer
to this question but a partial answer can be
obtained.
The Atomic Energy Commission,
established by the MacMahon Act in 1945,
placed complete control of the production of
fissionable materials in the hands of a panel
of civilian experts appointed by the
President. While not infallible, it is generally
agreed that the A.E.C. has functioned effectively.
Laboratories such as the Brookhaven
National Laboratory are consortia managed
by a group of private universities including
Hopkins. This arrangement of civilian (and
specifically university) involvement in
classified research has apparently been both
productive and satisfactory.
University and civilian involvement in
non-atomic classified research has taken the
form which now exists with A.P.L. That is,
the Department of the Navy or Army enters
into some kind of contractual arrangement
with a particular university.
Obviously arrangements of this type place
universities in an auspicious position to
serve as civilian monitors of military
research which is under their sponsership.
The following question arises: should
universities that enter into such agreements
serve in the capacity of a civilian monitor? In
-my opinion, a university's board of trustees
should not enter into such an arrangement
unless they are both qualified and willing to
serve in this capacity. In the absence of any
panel such as the A.E.C. I believe the
obligation to discharge these responsibilities
rests with the universitities involved.
Until yesterday, I had assumed that our
trustees and those members of the faculty
who serve on the A.P.L. advisory committee
held the security clearance required to
permit them to be fully cognizant of the
various classified projects being conducted
by the A.P.L. For example, is the laboratory
free to refuse a research project on such
grounds as: incomensurability with national
defense, or extreme hazard to life, property,
or natural resources?
In summary I see the University's
reationship to the A.P.L. as one in which we
represent our society's conscience in matters of military research. At the same time
we can catalyze the conversion of our swords
into plow shares.

The Academic Council is now considering faculty

at Hopkins. For the first time, the Academic Council
has to judge promotions all at once, rather than each
promotion separately. This is a wise approach to the
problem,for it permits a total assessment of the faculty
situation, which, hopefully, will allow a more judicious
examination of all factors involved in promotions.

itself more to bare monetary concerns than to a genuine
regard for academic quality. Junior faculty and
associate professors who find themselves passed over
because of financial reasons will be quite tempted to
leave for other schools that can offer them greater
prestige and a higher salary. Hopkins is already suffering from a shortage of faculty, or to be more exact,
faculty willing to teach; more faculty departures,
coupled with the present hiring freeze, could do serious
damage to the calibre and stature of the Hopkins
academic program.

Editors Note:

My views on the relationship of universities
within our society to classified research
were formed during the period of and immediately following the Second World War.
The MacMahon bill passed then enabled the
establishment of close civilian control over
our atomic energy program. The vital issue
today is essentially the issue that arose over
the control of atomic energy in 1945, namely,
should the application of science to the
development of military technology be
conducted solely by the military under
military secrecy or should it be conducted
under the guidance and full knowledge of
responsible, authorized civilian groups. I
took a stand in favor of civilian control in
1945 and I have no intentions of abandoning it.
I do not contend that our civilian agencies
for controlling and monitoring military
• research have been entirely successful, or as
effective as we would like. They have been, in
my opinion, infinitely better than no civilian
control at all. Without some civilian involvement, however imperfect it might be,
military research would vanish under the
cloak of complete military secrecy.
Some of you may doubt the capability of
the military-industrial complex to carry out
the development of military technology in
total secrecy. In 1942, the Manhattan District
was established under the Army Corps of
Engineers for the purposes of manufacturing fissionable materials. This was done
in complete secrecy. Not even the workers
who built the plants knew what they were
doing.
In the absence of a duly authorized civilian
control panel, university students, faculty,
administrators, and trustees are certainly
no less obligated than any other member of
our society for shouldering the responsibility
of adequately monitoring universty sponsored military research They have, in my
opinion, the greater obligation to see that
this responsibility is discharged.
How should civilian involvement in the

management of military research be
organized? I do not know the entire answer
to this question but a partial answer can be
obtained.
The Atomic Energy Commission,
established by the MacMahon Act in 1945,
placed complete control of the production of
fissionable materials in the hands of a panel
of civilian experts appointed by the
President. While not infallible, it is generally
agreed that the A.E.C. has functioned effectively.
Laboratories such as the Brookhaven
National Laboratory are consortia managed
by a group of private universities including
Hopkins. This arrangement of civilian (and
specifically university) involvement in
classified research has apparently been both
productive and satisfactory.
University and civilian involvement in
non-atomic classified research has taken the
form which now exists with A.P.L. That is,
the Department of the Navy or Army enters
into some kind of contractual arrangement
with a particular university.
Obviously arrangements of this type place
universities in an auspicious position to
serve as civilian monitors of military
research which is under their sponsership.
The following question arises: should
universities that enter into such agreements
serve in the capacity of a civilian monitor? In
-my opinion, a university's board of trustees
should not enter into such an arrangement
unless they are both qualified and willing to
serve in this capacity. In the absence of any
panel such as the A.E.C. I believe the
obligation to discharge these responsibilities
rests with the universitities involved.
Until yesterday, I had assumed that our
trustees and those members of the faculty
who serve on the A.P.L. advisory committee
held the security clearance required to
permit them to be fully cognizant of the
various classified projects being conducted
by the A.P.L. For example, is the laboratory
free to refuse a research project on such
grounds as: incomensurability with national
defense, or extreme hazard to life, property,
or natural resources?
In summary I see the University's
reationship to the A.P.L. as one in which we
represent our society's conscience in matters of military research. At the same time
we can catalyze the conversion of our swords
into plow shares.
